required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Blue Blockers at Night and Insomnia Symptoms
clinical_study.official_title: Blocking Nocturnal Blue Light to Treat Insomnia: A Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Under entrained conditions, humans maintain a consolidated nocturnal sleep episode that coincides with environmental darkness and endogenous melatonin secretion. Various factors, such as artificial light, can compromise this temporal harmony, resulting in sleep disruption. Light is the strongest synchronizer of the circadian clock, with direct inputs via the retinohypothalamic tract to brain centers regulating sleep and circadian rhythms. Evening light exposure can suppress melatonin secretion and worsen sleep. This is critical, since most individuals routinely expose themselves to light before bedtime. The high sensitivity of the circadian system to blue wavelength light indicates that modern light sources such as light-emitting diodes (LED) may have particularly deleterious effects on sleep. It is possible to selectively filter out blue light while maintaining other visible spectra with blue-blocking (BB) lenses. Wearing BB lenses before bedtime may present a simple, affordable, and safe method to improve sleep. None have yet investigated the effects of BB lenses on subjective and objective sleep in insomnia patients, while simultaneously exploring the effects on melatonin secretion.

detailed_description.textblock: This study seeks to investigate the impact of BB lenses on melatonin and sleep in insomnia patients using a randomized, placebo-controlled crossover study, with the aim of developing a novel non-pharmacological approach for the treatment of insomnia. 15 individuals with insomnia will wear either BB or placebo (clear) lenses for 2 hours preceding bedtime while at home, for 1 week in a cross-over design. Sleep quality will be documented while at home, at also melatonin secretion while in the laboratory. It is predicted that compared to placebo, wearing BB lenses for 2 hours preceding bedtime will attenuate bright light associated melatonin suppression and improve sleep.

primary_outcome.measure: Pittsburgh Insomnia Rating Scale-65 (PIRS65) Total Score
primary_outcome.description: Pittsburgh Insomnia Rating Scale-65; measures the self-reported severity of insomnia over the past week. Higher scores indicate worsened severity. There are 65 items, each scored on a 4-point scale from low-high on symptom severity or frequency. There is a Total score, and 3 subscales: Distress score (how bothersome the sleep impairment is), Sleep Parameters score (sleep quality), and Quality of Life score. For the total score scoring is done by summing the scores from questions 1-65. Minimum Score=0 (good); Maximum Score=195 (bad) For the distress score, scoring is done by summing the scores from questions 1-46. Minimum Score=0 (not bothered); Maximum Score=138 (severely bothered) For the sleep parameters score, scoring is done by summing the scores from questions 47-56. Minimum Score=0 (good sleep); Maximum Score=30 (disrupted sleep) For the quality of life score, scoring is done by summing the scores from questions 57-65. Minimum Score=0 (excellent); Maximum Score=27 (poor)

primary_outcome.measure: Pittsburgh Insomnia Rating Scale-65 (PIRS65) Total Score
primary_outcome.description: Pittsburgh Insomnia Rating Scale-65; measures the self-reported severity of insomnia over the past week. Higher scores indicate worsened severity. There are 65 items, each scored on a 4-point scale from low-high on symptom severity or frequency. There is a Total score, and 3 subscales: Distress score (how bothersome the sleep impairment is), Sleep Parameters score (sleep quality), and Quality of Life score. For the total score scoring is done by summing the scores from questions 1-65. Minimum Score=0 (good); Maximum Score=195 (bad) For the distress score, scoring is done by summing the scores from questions 1-46. Minimum Score=0 (not bothered); Maximum Score=138 (severely bothered) For the sleep parameters score, scoring is done by summing the scores from questions 47-56. Minimum Score=0 (good sleep); Maximum Score=30 (disrupted sleep) For the quality of life score, scoring is done by summing the scores from questions 57-65. Minimum Score=0 (excellent); Maximum Score=27 (poor)

secondary_outcome.measure: Sleep Efficiency (Time Spent Asleep Divided by Total Time in Bed) Determined With Wrist-worn Accelerometry
secondary_outcome.description: Wrist-worn accelerometry gives an estimate of time spent asleep, time spent in bed, and sleep efficiency can be calculated from this. Sleep efficiency is calculated as time spent asleep divided by total time in bed. Here, we considered the mean calculated sleep efficiency over each 7-day treatment period.

secondary_outcome.measure: Sleep Efficiency (Time Spent Asleep Divided by Total Time in Bed) Determined With Wrist-worn Accelerometry
secondary_outcome.description: Wrist-worn accelerometry gives an estimate of time spent asleep, time spent in bed, and sleep efficiency can be calculated from this. Sleep efficiency is calculated as time spent asleep divided by total time in bed. Here, we considered the mean calculated sleep efficiency over each 7-day treatment period.

intervention.description: Participants will wear blue blocking lenses each night for 1 week for 2 hours preceding bedtime.
Participants will wear clear lenses each night for 1 week for 2 hours preceding bedtime.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Insomnia for at least 1 month based on Insomnia Symptoms Questionnaire
Exclusion Criteria:
- obstructive sleep apnea; narcolepsy; periodic leg movement disorder
- currently shift worker
- psychiatric or neurologic disorders
- deep vein thrombosis
- current cigarette smoker
- currently taking beta-blockers
- pregnant/breastfeeding
- children less than 1 year old at home
- excessive daily caffeine intake

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Medical Sciences (in Medicine)

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: BB First (7 d), Then Clear (7 d), Separated by 4-wk Washout
group.description: Wearing of BB first for 7 days, followed by Clear lenses for 7 days, separated by 4-week washout period Blue blocking (BB) lenses: Participants will wear blue blocking lenses each night for 1 week for 2 hours preceding bedtime. Clear lenses: Participants will wear clear lenses each night for 1 week for 2 hours preceding bedtime

group.title: Clear First (7 ), Then BB (7 d), Separated by 4-wk Washout
group.description: Wearing Clear lenses first for 7 days, followed by BB lenses for 7 days, separated by a 4-week washout period

group.title: Blue Blocking (BB)/Clear
group.description: Wearing of BB lenses. Blue blocking (BB) lenses: Participants will wear blue blocking lenses each night for 1 week for 2 hours preceding bedtime. Clear lenses: Participants will wear clear lenses each night for 1 week for 2 hours preceding bedtime.

outcome.title: Sleep Efficiency (Time Spent Asleep Divided by Total Time in Bed) Determined With Wrist-worn Accelerometry
outcome.description: Wrist-worn accelerometry gives an estimate of time spent asleep, time spent in bed, and sleep efficiency can be calculated from this. Sleep efficiency is calculated as time spent asleep divided by total time in bed. Here, we considered the mean calculated sleep efficiency over each 7-day treatment period.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
